::: {.column width="75%" .incremental}
- A robust R package to calculate the [Rate of Change (RoC)]{.text-highlight-seal_brown} in [palaeoecological]{.text-highlight-seal_brown} time series
- incorporates age uncertainties, standardisation of taxonomic richness, and multivariate dissimilarity coefficients

:::

::::

## Rate of Vegetation Change (RoC)

```{r}
#| label: science 1
include_local_figure("RoC/Figure1.jpeg")
```

_[Mottl, O.]{.text-highlight-black .bold} & Flantua, S.G.A._, Bhatta K.B., Felde, V.A., Giesecke, T., Goring, S., Grimm, E.C., Haberle, S., Hooghiemstra H., Ivory, S., Kune≈°, P., Wolters, S., Seddon A.W.R, Williams J.W. (2021), [Global acceleration in rates of vegetation change over the past 18,000 years]{.text-highlight-teal .italic}. **Science** 372: 860-864.

## Rate of Vegetation Change (RoC)

```{r}
#| label: science 2
include_local_figure("RoC/Figure2.jpeg")
```



## Rate of Vegetation Change (RoC)

<br>

::: {.incremental}

- Rates of vegetation change during the Late Holocene are now as fast or faster than during the Last Deglaciation
- The start of the increased global rates of vegetation change is surprisingly early, about 3000-4000 years ago
- Ecosystem turnover rates have been rapidly accelerating over the last century, so our work suggests that modern acceleration is just the tip of the iceberg
- This is the first quantitative detection analysis of global biodiversity changes over the last 18,000 years, based on 1181 records from the Neotoma 
   + an amazing global community of scientists working together!

:::
